comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Several of these photos and similar ones in the Powerhouse Museum Collection have dates hand written on them near the title.  This is 27 September 1901 (a Friday).  

Perhaps the (unnamed and uncredited) photographer was commissioned by the NSW Government to record  the Rocks after the bubonic plague outbreak in 1900, when planning 'resumption' of the area.  The prints are  in the State Records NSW (and now on Flickr);  some of the glass negatives found their way into the Tyrrell collection.  

Not an earth-shattering idea, but it might help explain the existence and dating of these photos.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Thanks, I missed that handwritten date on the curb - will update the caption. This series - NRS 4481 - comes from the Government Printing Office; the photos were taken by (unnamed) departmental officers c.1870-c.1920. We added some "plague" photos to Flickr at the end of last year. They were taken by Mr. John Degotardi, Jr., photographer from the Department of Public Works.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Thanks State Records NSW for the plague photos link - lifeasdaddy let me know about them a while ago when discussing this photo - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2844602875/ . The Degotardi pictures are wonderfully graphic and interesting, but to my (untrained) eye, they have a different style, composition, lighting, and content to this series (and those in the Tyrrell collection).

comment.author: 20958381@N08

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: do you mean 1830s btw?

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: so SRNSW licenses say it was called Jack's Delight in 1837 when Thomas Jones was granted the license and in 1839 when it was granted to Edward Brady. Prior to this It seems to have been the Sailors Delight and the Sailors Delight license was at Essex Lane and Frasers Lane before it You can see these entries at srwww.records.nsw.gov.au/indexsearch/searchform.aspx?id=69 but not sure if they give the exact address in the full record SRNSW should be able to help you. Possibly (as it was originally listed as Essex Lane) it was actually at the corner of Essex Lane and Cumberland Street and maybe became the Forth & Clyde then the Coach & Horses, all of which were on the corner of this street. But ... there were four corners and they possibly all had a pub! Sorry - if I come across anything else I'll let you know :-)

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/agrippinamaior] Great stuff Nic! Thanks! [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sugarsugar_au] So, if Jack's Delight was previously known as Sailor's Delight, which appears to be the case, then your hotel's location was on one of the four corners of the intersection one block south (to the right) of this view - this photo shows the north-east corner of the intersection of Cumberland and Little Essex Streets. Here are some photos of the relevant intersection of Cumberland and Essex Streets, presented clock-wise. The north-west corner - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/8431051751/] The north-east corner - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/3863063707/] The south-east corner - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/8188368909/] And lastly (almost) the south-west corner, the location of the Coach & Horses Hotel - Bear in mind these photos were taken more than 60 years after Jack's Delight was trading, and the original building may have already been demolished and replaced.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sugarsugar_au] Okay, ignore all that ... there's been a bit of confusion between Essex LANE and Essex STREET. The Coach & Horses Hotel was on the corner of Cumberland and Essex STREET, but Jack's Delight, formerly Sailor's Delight, was on the corner of Cumberland Street and Essex LANE. Essex Lane (also known as Frazer Lane, and the section east of Gloucester Street as Brown Bear Lane) became Little Essex Street. Which means we are indeed looking at the correct intersection already! So, to start again ... this is the north-west corner - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/3810910116/] We are already looking at the north-east corner. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/3863847256/] The Old Erin-go-bragh Hotel stood on the south-east corner. See 1890 map here for context (shows street numbers, hotel names) - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_zoomify/2008/D00663/a1367458.html And this is close to the south-west corner - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/8189453150/]

comment.author: 61753330@N06
comment._content:
Thank you so much!!  It has been literally doing my head in trying to find out the location as William Anderson, Publican of the Jack's delight was my GGGG Grandfather and while I have a great deal of the Ancestry the pub was eluding my efforts to find the location.
William Anderson was the Publican of 'Jacks Delight' 1838, Publican certificate no 38/288, granted 4/7/1838 for the Hotel "Jack's Delight" costing 25 pounds sterling.

I'm still not sure where specifically the Jacks delight stood, could someone clarify (feeling a little brain weary at the moment.)

He had a very colourful history, he actually came out on the 'Red Rover' in 1832 as a shipwright and met his second wife Bridgett Mead on board, leaving his first wife and small son behind, his wife then was employed as a nanny for the Rev John Vincent before he moved to Penrith NSW .

William was Buried in the Waverley Cemetary after being removed from a cemetary which stood where Central railway stands in Sydney today. Burial service performed by Rev John McGave

Feel free to visually consume all the E-Cupcakes you like as thanks for your efforts  :)

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sugarsugar_au] Sorry if our comments were a bit confusing, to clarify ... Jack's Delight (previously known as Sailor's Delight) would have stood on one of the four corners of Cumberland Street and Little Essex Street (previously known variously as Essex Lane, Frazer Lane, and Brown Bear Lane). This 1890 map shows the relevant intersection - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_zoomify/2008/D00663/a1367458.html - and the three photos above show how some of these corners appeared in 1900. Hopefully in time we can narrow down which corner for you ...

comment.author: 61753330@N06
comment._content:
Thank you Pelle, I thought I was just being dense and had missed something :) it's good to know I had narrowed it down to the right area overall.  
I have spent countless years poring over endless photos with a mixture of wistful nostalgic longing  (always had a fascination with old buildings and Australian history from an early age) and serious genealogical research and have often seen insightful posts by yourself and others in this thread that have helped me identify certain areas and buildings, it's been good to be able to see the research and thought processes and finally to discuss the possibilities with those more knowledgeable first hand.

What I do find curious is that in my previous research on Trove when looking through SMH publican's License renewals I have found the Jack's Delight to be listed as two different addresses, one being Cumberland st and another being George st, both on William Anderson and Edward Brady.

comment.author: 61753330@N06
comment._content: I've been thinking more on this and finding the location, doing some detective work regarding the Coroners Court holding meetings at the Jack's Delight and the proximity of the Coroners court next to the Sailors home and the fact that the Jack's delight was previously known as the 'Sailor's Delight', a link maybe? clutching at straws more like ;) but I am determined if possible to find where this hotel was! This snippet from the SMH Thursday 10 August 1837 states the Hotel was on Cumberland st.... CORONER'S INQUESTS. An inquest was held on Saturday, at the Jack's Delight, Cumberland-street, on the body of a labouring man named Henry Split, who died in a fit that morning. Verdict-Died by the visitation of God. Could it have been on the site of the the Observer hotel which is directly across the road, as in one publicans renewal of Jack's it stated George ST, all I could find Historically was this: The Observer Tavern was constructed in 1848 as a two storeyed, six room public house. The tavern was owned by Robert White from 1847 till his death in 1875, after which the hotel was managed by his trustees, Benjamin Palmer and Thomas Moore. The land was resumed in 1901 under The Observatory Hill Resumption Act, 1900. In 1908 Tooth and Co. purchased the site and held freehold title. The Sydney Cove Redevelopment Authority resumed the land in 1977. But then Jack's is listed as Cumberland street in other renewals , I'm hitting a brick wall, maybe I will never know but for now I'll keep digging. There was also a Shoemaker named Dawson that appeared to have owned the building as you can see in this advertisement: PS. searcher63 contact me regarding Ancestry :)
